p: Analyses of the effects of temperature on vector-borne pathogen transmission have focused primarily on the basic reproduction number R 0 through the effects of temperature on the aforementioned vector and pathogen traits [ 11, 15, 16]. Defined as the average number of secondary infections arising from a primary infection in a fully susceptible population, R 0 is a fundamentally important epidemiological quantity, because it is informative about the conditions under which a pathogen can invade, or be eliminated from, a host population. The generation interval, which is the period of time separating sequential infections, is the temporal analogue of R 0. Through a fundamental mathematical relationship [ 17], R 0 and the generation interval are related to the epidemic growth rate r, which is defined as the per capita change in incidence per unit time and characterizes the dynamics of early-stage epidemic growth in a susceptible population. Because the relationship between r and temperature has never been characterized for arboviruses, there is little scientific basis for understanding how epidemic growth rates may be related to temperature.
